creator: wgrinfeld@hotmail.com
text:
When accessing an HTML or XUL page in Mozilla via the Tomcat server (as opposed 
to accessing it from Apache) using port 8080 , makes that the XBL elements 
declared are not shown

Created attachment 392
HTML test 5 for XBL
creator: wgrinfeld@hotmail.com

text:
A workaround to this problem exists by using HTML + XBL and specifying the full 
path to the CSS/XBL used: this way, Apache will find the file for Tomcat, or so 
it seems. This does not work for XUL + XBL however.
creator: wgrinfeld@hotmail.com
remm@apache.org
text:
That's very likely to be a content type problem, since Tomcat doesn't know the
mime type for .xbl, and it would be served as text/plain.

creator: remm@apache.org
text:
So, can you try adding XBL with the text/xml type to your web.xml, and see if 
the problem goes away ?

creator: wgrinfeld@hotmail.com
text:
Adding the following to web.xml did not change the problem, though it could be 
a bug in Mozilla.

  <mime-mapping>
    <extension>xbl</extension>
    <mime-type>text/xml</mime-type>
  </mime-mapping>
  <mime-mapping>
    <extension>xml</extension>
    <mime-type>text/xml</mime-type>
  </mime-mapping>
  <mime-mapping>
    <extension>css</extension>
    <mime-type>text/css</mime-type>
  </mime-mapping>

creator: wgrinfeld@hotmail.com
text:
Got it to work on Tomcat 4 by 
- adding mime types for xbl,css,xml to web.xml
- adding absolute path including port number in CSS
  e.g.
   -moz-binding: url('http://myserver:8080/capital/xulnote.xbl#MyTextBox');
  or using inline style 
  e.g.
  <box style="-moz-binding: url('xulnote.xbl#MyTextBox');"/>

Did not get it to work on Tomcat 3.2.1, but did not try hard.
